fields.value: The Fifty American States in Space and Time: Applying Conditionally Autoregressive Models

dsDescriptionValue.value: Spatial conditionally autoregressive (CAR) models in a hierarchical Bayesian framework can be informative for understanding state politics, or any similar population of border-defined observations. This article explains how a hierarchical CAR model is specified and estimated and then uses Monte Carlo analyses to show when the CAR model offers efficiency gains. We apply this model to data structures common to state politics: A cross-sectional example replicates Erikson, Wright & McIver's (1993) Statehouse Democracy model, and a multilevel panel model example replicates Margalit's (2013) study of social welfare policy preferences. The CAR model fits better in each case and some inferences differ from models that ignore geographic correlation.

publicationCitation.value: Jackson, Joshua L. and James E. Monogan III. "The Fifty American States in Space and Time: Applying Conditionally Autoregressive Models." Political Science Research & Methods.

files.description: R script that defines the function "CAR.Proper," which estimates a Bayesian conditional autoregressive model using the "proper CAR" specification. This works for a cross-sectional linear model and loads necessary input packages spdep, MCMCpack, and mvtnorm.
files.label: CARproper.R

dataFile.description: R script that defines the function "CAR.Proper," which estimates a Bayesian conditional autoregressive model using the "proper CAR" specification. This works for a cross-sectional linear model and loads necessary input packages spdep, MCMCpack, and mvtnorm.

files.description: Raw coda output from OpenBUGS. These files, for each of the reported models, are called by Convergence_Tests.R to compute Gelman-Rubin statistics to test for nonconvergence. These files also could be used to produce density plots or other result summaries not reported if any interested user wished to. The coda output files are all contained in this 7z-formatted compressed folder.
files.label: ConvergenceTests.7z

dataFile.description: Raw coda output from OpenBUGS. These files, for each of the reported models, are called by Convergence_Tests.R to compute Gelman-Rubin statistics to test for nonconvergence. These files also could be used to produce density plots or other result summaries not reported if any interested user wished to. The coda output files are all contained in this 7z-formatted compressed folder.

files.description: This program is the same as logitTest.R, but the variable named x2 is given a spatial correlation structure. This program calls the functions logitMCindep.txt and logitMCcar.txt and runs these models through R2OpenBUGS. Hence, you must be using a Windows machine with OpenBUGS installed to run this program.
files.label: logitTestCorrel.R

dataFile.description: This program is the same as logitTest.R, but the variable named x2 is given a spatial correlation structure. This program calls the functions logitMCindep.txt and logitMCcar.txt and runs these models through R2OpenBUGS. Hence, you must be using a Windows machine with OpenBUGS installed to run this program.

files.description: This program simulates dichotomous observations with a spatially correlated error in the utility function, then evaluates how a standard Bayesian logit model compares to a CAR logit model. This program calls the functions logitMCindep.txt and logitMCcar.txt and runs these models through R2OpenBUGS. Hence, you must be using a Windows machine with OpenBUGS installed to run this program.
files.label: logitTest.R

dataFile.description: This program simulates dichotomous observations with a spatially correlated error in the utility function, then evaluates how a standard Bayesian logit model compares to a CAR logit model. This program calls the functions logitMCindep.txt and logitMCcar.txt and runs these models through R2OpenBUGS. Hence, you must be using a Windows machine with OpenBUGS installed to run this program.
